org.gamecontrolplus

Class ControlIO

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gamecontrolplus.ControlIO
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Runnable, PCPconstants

    public class ControlIO
extends Object
implements Runnable, PCPconstants

    ControllIO is the base class for using controllers in Processing. It provides methods to retrieve information about the connected devices and to get the input data from them.
    To get a ControllIO object you to use the getInstance() Method. To get started you should use the deviceListToText(...) or the devicesToText(...) to see if what control devices you have attached and their details.

    To react on button events you can plug methods, that are called when a button is pressed, released or while a button is pressed.

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static ControlIO getInstance(processing.core.PApplet i_parent)
        Use this method to get a ControllIO instance.
        This must be called from the setup method immediately after the call to size(...)
        Parameters:
        i_parent - PApplet, the application ProControl Plus is running in
        Returns:
        ControllIO, an instance of ControllIO

        public void dispose()

        Returns the number of available Devices
        Returns:
        the number of available devices

      • getDevices

        public List<ControlDevice> getDevices()
        Get the list of USB devices connected. This will not 'open' or 'close' any of the devices for you.

      • getDevice

        public ControlDevice getDevice(int i_deviceNumber)
        Use this method to get a Device based on its number. This method will 'open' the device so that you can use it.
        Use printDevices to see what devices are available on your system.
        Parameters:
        i_deviceNumber - int, number of the device to open
        Returns:
        ControllDevice, the device corresponding to the given number or name

      • getDevice

        public ControlDevice getDevice(String i_deviceName)
        Use this method to get a Device based on its name. This method will 'open' the device so that you can use it.
        Use printDevices to see what devices are available on your system.
        Parameters:
        i_deviceName - String, name of the device to open

      • getMatchedDevice

        public ControlDevice getMatchedDevice(String filename)
        Find and return the ControlDevice that matches the configuration described in the specified file.
        If an exact match can't be found give the user an option to configure another device.
        Parameters:
        filename - the name of the configuration file
        Returns:
        the device or null if no device is configured.

      • getMatchedDeviceSilent

        public ControlDevice getMatchedDeviceSilent(String filename)
        Find and return the ControlDevice that matches the configuration described in the specified file.
        The user is not given the chance to configure another device if an exact match is not found, in this situation the method returns null.
        Parameters:
        filename - the name of the configuration file
        Returns:
        the device or null if no device is configured.

      • getMatchedDevice

        public ControlDevice getMatchedDevice(Configuration config)
        Find and return the ControlDevice that matches the specified configuration.
        If an exact match can't be found give the user an option to configure another device.
        Parameters:
        config - the configuration to match
        Returns:
        the device or null if no device is configured.

      • getMatchedDeviceSilent

        public ControlDevice getMatchedDeviceSilent(Configuration config)
        Find and return the ControlDevice that matches the specified configuration.
        The user is not given the chance to configure another device if an exact match is not found, in this situation the method returns null.
        Parameters:
        config - the configuration to match
        Returns:
        the device or null if no device is configured.

      • finishedConfig

        public void finishedConfig(ControlDevice dev)
        Used internally to signal when a configuration has finished.
        Parameters:
        dev - the configured device or null if the configuration was cancelled.

      • pre

        public void pre()
        Updates the devices, to get the actual data before a new frame is drawn

        Controllers are now polled in a separate thread to get independent from the framerate of the sketch

      • plug

        public void plug(Object i_object,
        String i_methodName,
        int i_eventType,
        int i_intputDevice,
        int i_input)

        Plug is a handy method to handle incoming button events. To create a plug you have to implement a method that reacts on the events. To plug a method you need to give ControllIO the method name, the event type you want to react on and the device and button. If your method is inside a class you have to give ControllIO a reference to it.

        If you want to handle the events of a simple button, you only have to implement a method without parameters. To react on the events of a hat you method needs to receive two float values, so that ProControl Plus can send you the x and y values of the hat.

        Parameters:
        i_object - Object: the object with the method to plug
        i_methodName - String: the name of the method that has to be plugged
        i_eventType - constant: can be ControllIO.ON_PRESS, ControllIO.ON_RELEASE or ControllIO.WHILE_PRESS
        i_intputDevice - int: the number of the device that triggers the plug
        i_input - int: the number of the button that triggers the plug

      • plug

        public void plug(String i_methodName,
        int i_eventType,
        int i_intputDevice,
        int i_input)

        Plug is a handy method to handle incoming button events. To create a plug you have to implement a method that reacts on the events. To plug a method you need to give ControllIO the method name, the event type you want to react on and the device and button. If your method is inside a class you have to give ControllIO a reference to it.

        If you want to handle the events of a simple button, you only have to implement a method without parameters. To react on the events of a hat you method needs to receive two float values, so that ProControl Plus can send you the x and y values of the hat.

        Parameters:
        i_methodName - String: the name of the method that has to be plugged
        i_eventType - constant: can be ControllIO.ON_PRESS, ControllIO.ON_RELEASE or ControllIO.WHILE_PRESS
        i_intputDevice - int: the number of the device that triggers the plug
        i_input - int: the number of the button that triggers the plug

      • plug

        public void plug(Object i_object,
        String i_methodName,
        int i_eventType,
        String i_intputDevice,
        String i_input)

        Plug is a handy method to handle incoming button events. To create a plug you have to implement a method that reacts on the events. To plug a method you need to give ControllIO the method name, the event type you want to react on and the device and button. If your method is inside a class you have to give ControllIO a reference to it.

        If you want to handle the events of a simple button, you only have to implement a method without parameters. To react on the events of a hat you method needs to receive two float values, so that ProControl Plus can send you the x and y values of the hat.

        Parameters:
        i_object - Object: the object with the method to plug
        i_methodName - String: the name of the method that has to be plugged
        i_eventType - constant: can be ControllIO.ON_PRESS, ControllIO.ON_RELEASE or ControllIO.WHILE_PRESS
        i_intputDevice - String: the name of the device that triggers the plug
        i_input - String: the name of the input that triggers the plug. Can be system name or name from the configuration file.

      • plug
